data.title: Princess Margaret of Denmark’s historic French Riviera home is heading under the hammer
data.meta_description: The Côte d’Azur estate where Princess Margaret of Denmark made her home has recently been listed for sale at a no-reserve auction.
data.text:
The Côte d’Azur estate where Princess Margaret of Denmark and Prince René of Bourbon-Parma made their home has recently been listed for sale at a no-reserve auction.

Overlooking the French Riviera, the one-of-a-kind residence is known as La Carriere, which dates back to the 1920s.

The majestic manor was built into the stone walls of a fortress, melding rustic charm with modern luxury, while the walls provide the ultimate in privacy and security, according to TopTenRealEstateDeals.

The property is scheduled to head under the hammer on May 16, with the listed price guide prior to auction set at $12 million.

Arched windows-and-stone accents give the villa a unique and enduring style. Antique high-beamed ceilings and a majestic fireplace add grandeur to the living room.

The Five-bedroom, six-bathroom home offers plenty of room for family and guests, while a spacious kitchen and gorgeous formal dining room are perfect for entertaining.

MORE: Proptrack rental report for the March quarter

Multiple terraces and turrets offer generous views of the Riviera, and the rooftop deck also boasts a hot tub.

The landscaped grounds include lush lawns, mature trees, beautiful gardens, plus a pool surrounded by a stone grotto. The pool complex includes a detached studio.

Margaret, the fifth child of Prince Valdemar of Denmark and his wife Princess Marie of Orléans, was a cousin of Queen Elizabeth of England, as well as rulers of Russia, Greece, Hanover and Orléans.

She married Prince René, with whom she would have four children. The couple resided mostly in France but were forced to flee the Nazis during World War II.

Escaping through Spain to Portugal to New York, the princess worked making hats while her husband worked at a gas company and her oldest daughter as a shop clerk to make ends meet until the war was over and they were able to return to Paris.

Côte d’Azur refers to the coastline of the Mediterranean Sea in southern France. One of the world’s first resort areas, it has long been a summer destination for Europe’s royalty, world celebrities, and artists, including Pablo Picasso and Henri Matisse.

La Carriere is located in the town of Villefranche-sur-Mer, nestled between Nice and Monaco — with Bill Gates, Elton John and Bono all known to own villas nearby.
